description: From Middle English attraccioun, from Old French attraction, from Latin attractio from past participle of attrahō (= ad + trahō), equivalent to attract +‎ -ion.

examples: The Moon is held in its orbit by the attraction of the Earth's gravity.
I felt a strange attraction towards the place.

entries.meaning: (countable) An event, location, or business that has a tendency to draw interest from visitors, and in many cases, local residents.
examples: The new mall should be a major attraction.
Star Tours is a very cool Disney World attraction.

entries.meaning: (chess) The sacrifice of pieces in order to expose the enemy king.
(linguistics) An error in language production that incorrectly extends a feature from one word in a sentence to another, e.g. when a verb agrees with a noun other than its subject.
